intro: Tepuia tatei var. chimantana, commonly known as the Chimantá tepuia, is a unique species native to the tepuis of Venezuela. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its striking, tubular flowers that range in color from white to deep violet. The plant typically grows in rocky, nutrient-poor soils at high altitudes, showcasing its adaptation to extreme environments. Its leaves are usually opposite and elliptical, with a waxy surface to reduce water loss. Due to its restricted habitat and ecological significance, it is considered a rare and vulnerable species.
